direction.raw_text: The Old Town is quiet.  It's very early in the twisted streets of this ancient ghetto.  Dark corners casting a medieval spell over a modern century oblivious to their romance and mystery. The River is the dividing line.  Elegant gardens on the opposite bank embracing the monotonous solemnity of the New Town, tower steeples silhouetted against the sombre sky. An empty motor bus rattles along a deserted street. A Gothic bridge links the two halves of the strange city. Its half-moon arches becoming circles as they meet their reflections in the water.  Thin mist swirls over the cobblestones above. A few boats in the water.  Fishermen casting their lines in silence.  One or two lights now burning in buildings beyond. In the Old Town Square the great clock on the cathedral strikes six.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes filled with terror, beads of sweat crawling on his brow. He stands in the middle of a murky courtyard, perfectly still.  Waiting.  Watching. The balconies overlooking on successive floors, looming all around him, are empty.  All is quiet. The man's name is EDUARD.  He dares not move for fear of missing a single sound.  And then he hears it.  A small noise of movement nearby.  He runs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs alone in the dim light of the deserted morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Running for his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Running on sheer pumping fear, long after the verge of collapse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coming out into the light, but by no means out of danger, he allows himself a brief pause, gasping for air, just for a moment looking back into the gloom, starting to retreat again even as he does, then turning running ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs on, past boarded-up houses and shuttered inns, strange relics of the Middle Ages casting frightening shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eduard appears suddenly, quickly flattens himself back against the large notice board that covers the wall here, layers of expressionistic theatre and film posters pasted on it. He breathes painfully in short bursts, as silently as he can.  He watches the corner he's just come from, the ornate archway through which any pursuer must emerge. Nothing there.  But then a shadow moves. Eduard's shoulders tense.  His eyes widen.  He holds his breath. The shadow ... spreading ... Eduard edges away ever so slowly, keeping his unblinking gaze on the archway, backing off, one arm brushing the notice board as he feels his way along it, macabre images on the posters, some torn and incomplete, revealing other fragments behind, Eduard's eyes staring constant, no noise here at all and -- A HAND!  clamps over his face from behind.  All of a sudden and out of absolutely nowhere and not a thing he can do about it. But he tries, his hands coming up to grip the arm that grasps him, an arm of iron. The hand is huge.  It covers Eduard's face almost entirely, only one eye gaping bloodshot through the fingers, ghastly fingers that, just for a second, seem almost inhuman, perhaps even fingers that seem incompatible on the same hand, a hand covered in scar tissue, starting to squeeze as it pulls Eduard swiftly away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clacketing incessantly under slightly more agile and refined fingers.  Beyond these, another row of desks.  And beyond that another, the office workers in their neat suits tapping away. And beyond that another, at which one worker scribbles furiously at his figures, the next rolls a new sheet into his typewriter, the next answers his clanging telephone, the next rifles through the pages of a massive record book, the next sits erect in his chair playing his machine like a piano, and the last, by the window, dusty light streaming across him, contemplatively taps the end of a pencil onto his desk.  This is KAFKA. A rather tall young man with a kind, sensitive face. sensitive perhaps because his eyes, ears, and nose seem slightly bigger and more inquiring than most, and his gaze one of almost unrelenting intensity. He's looking off at something now. A desk, not very far from his own.  But empty.  The chair pushed squarely under it.  The typewriter covered. Kafka is wondering why -- when his concentration is interrupted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka turns to see BURGEL, a creep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burgel just won't go away.  Kafka tries to get on with his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stare at each other with mutual antagonism.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waddles away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kafka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The keeper of the files is still waiting for your final summation of the Erlanger claim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave it to him yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (doesn't understand) You didn't give it to me .
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I left it in his office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you see him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen him.  I don't believe there is a keeper of the files.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's usually in the storage room sorting things out.  He can't close the file on a case until he has the concluding report.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has it, he just hasn't noticed it yet, all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's to say he ever will?  He's a timid old man and quite careful not to tread on anyone's toes -- In fact, I'm the only one he trusts and he wouldn't even look at a document if it didn't first come through me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In an organization as efficient as ours, if a document once in a great while gets lost it might never be found at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tiring of this) Burgel, I thought it would be easier, as long as I was passing -- BURGEL But I'm the messenger.  An error like this damages my credibility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your credibility -- yes, it's well known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flushed) When I deliver a message the very act of delivering it, you might say, gives it an official stamp, and only in this way are both the sender and the receiver satisfied that it was delivered at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll commit that to memory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your position in this firm is not unassailable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Has one more look over at the empty desk before returning to his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The desks make a checkerboard pattern of the huge floor as Burgel calculates his path among them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes up the stairs to the top landing.  He knocks on a door.  Waits.  Knocks again.  Leans a little closer to listen for a moment, then goes away back down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes through the door that divides the stairs from the hall, goes to knock on the door of the first apartment down here.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry to disturb you -- I wonder if you know where my friend Eduard is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't hear you! -- You'd better come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes in tentatively, seeing the CONCIERGE in a far corner of the cluttered room, in bed, covers tucked right up to her chin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't want to bother you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you have.  What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing upstairs) My friend Eduard, I wonder if you've seen him?  He hasn't been in to work, I thought he might be ill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Concierge trudges up to the top floor, Kafka following guiltily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She treats him like dirt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't have to get out of bed -- I could have taken the key.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'm sure you could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The door unlocks and the two of them come in.  Kafka goes to open the window curtain.  He turns around to see the Concierge already poking about in drawers. He ignores her and looks around the room on his own.  Eduard isn't here.  Nothing else seems out of place.  He wonders instead how he can dissuade the Concierge from her unbelievable snooping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Concierge takes a tie from one of the drawers and models it over her own ample chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him indignantly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he's not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think you ought to do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The manners of a tramp!  It's my house, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka is in another section of the building, finding his way through a department he's vaguely unfamiliar with.  He searches out a particular person -- a strikingly beautiful woman with flaming hair and wild eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Rossmann?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks around from a file cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He follows her to a counter where someone stamps the document she thrusts forward without even glancing at her or it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka watches her go -- then notices some smarmy young clerks giggling over what they suppose was a romantic rebuff.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Kafka -- I work upstairs in Accident -- GABRIELA I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a friend of Eduard Raban's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would you suppose so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- well, I thought he once mentioned -- GABRIELA (shuts file cabinet) One of you must be mistaken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, but I just wondered -- GABRIELA (brushing past him) Excuse me, I have to copy this for Central Docketing by 2:30.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Burgel sees Kafka coming back in toward his desk, immediately walks to intersect him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka ignores him utterly, leaving Burgel standing clutching his files with a sour expression. Kafka pauses at Eduard's desk, still untouched, then continues on to his own.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're late -- I knew it would happen one day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Partitioned off from the rest, but commanding a full view of all.  Through the glass windows the CHIEF CLERK, a stern- Looking fellow, notices Kafka and takes his watch out of his pocket for a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EVENING RINGS, signalling the end of the work day.  The office workers clear their desks, start to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The office workers stream down the stairs that wind around a central elevator shaft, the gated elevator grinding upwards at the same time. When Kafka reaches the ground floor he passes a pair of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: conferring together -- and does a double-take when he hears his name mentioned -- then sees the two men shake hands conclusively and turn away.  Kafka continues walking away himself, worried about his future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The office workers pour out of the building, all going in different directions.  Three of them get jammed in the doorway, untangle themselves, and Kafka is the next to emerge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lively place, crowded with chattering, smoking, arguing students, poets, painters ... Kafka joins a group of friends.  It's clear that this is a regular gathering and, from their warm reception, considered incomplete without him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka cringes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka shrugs shyly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is our friend Anna who works with us on the magazine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been hearing all about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Kafka -- I championed your virtues.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to hear them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anna's new to the city -- we wouldn't frighten her needlessly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've lived all my life in this city
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: it frightens me.  As it draws me closer into its web.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is an ancient lament.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but do you realize why? -- it has no present .
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm hoping to live in the Old Quarter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even the so-called New Town isn't so new.  Only the people.  People of the future living in buildings of the past. (abruptly) Has anyone seen Eduard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who? My friend Eduard from the office -- I've brought him here lots of times
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: you used to marvel at his travel stories.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'you mean, oh him?  He's a perfectly nice person, he's never missed a day before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps he's taken up with those traveling players you two were so fond of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's me who always wanted to run away with them -- except that that life would be far too hectic for me.  I'm worried about him, no one's seen him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't you ever called in sick and gone roaming about, free of responsibility to anyone, if only for a day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you work for a medical firm you can't call in sick.  They know malingerers like a dog knows fleas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You work in the insurance department?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have been hearing the sordid side then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be pleased -- you constantly inspire people to take an interest in your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should think it's very interesting work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father always said I had no ambition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Smoke heavier in the air, the coffee house more crowded with strange groups of characters.  Kafka and his friends preparing to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BIZZLEBEK The owner of the voice.  A man sitting at the bar nearby, turning on his stool to face them.  A dissipated dandy of a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turning round again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bizz1ebek turns round again, with a bored sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks about, characterizing various coffee house types:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's GABRIELA from the office.  Kafka is surprised to see her, instinctively walking over to where she's sitting at a far table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna smiles.  She's interested in Kafka.   (Which means we must see this warm attractive girl as a threat, a curse, a trap!)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The cabaret will be packed this time of night -- we'll never get in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it has to be the cabaret because there's nowhere else to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home, I think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (head on Ernst's shoulder) You know I can't stay up late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home is the last resort --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (introducing him)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know Bizzlebek -- the gravedigger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stonecutter , if you please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sculptor , if only he'd admit it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one should admit being an artist unless they're paid for it.  If you go to the cabaret mention my name -- they'll find a table for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bizzlebek has ways and means denied lesser mortals.  It comes from working in the cemetery all day -- he's able to transcent the physical world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- it only makes me view people dispassionately as so many ... slabs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quartz ... slate ... gravel ... granite ... flint ... (and then) Marble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My God, look, he's marching forward willingly to make human contact.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: --On the other hand, is an enticement.  Kafka can't help walking towards her.  Sitting with her own friends, though there is something less than friendly about them.  Two men, two women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka feels as awkward as she knows he feels.  He looks to her friends, expecting an introduction, but no one makes a move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka nods goodbye and walks away, berating himself for banality.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as Kafka comes over) Hello again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen you here before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you looked?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- nice to know life exists outside the office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ironic) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka resists going along with the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Julius is a little drunk.  The others help him with his coat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, really, I have to go home too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're keeping him from his true vocation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, he consists of writing. We wouldn't be his friends if we didn't threaten his solitude!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Has a private moment with Kafka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures in the direction of the River, and the castle that looms on a far hill beyond, huge and brooding, regally dominating the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (The majesty of marriage is what he fears she represents. This innocent scene could very well be a subjective Kafkaesque nightmare as sinister in its own way as any of the more outright horrific scenes to come.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (The castle of marriage tempts him -- but would suffocate him.)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tried finding a place on Castle Hill when I arrived.  I wanted to share the majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only majestic from here. When you get closer you see it for what it really is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A glorified office block.  They keep all the old records there -- the final resting place for facts and figures that have ceased to matter in the world of the living.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, as long as I admire it from afar it shouldn't worry me if it's hollow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's more than hollow.  It's stillborn.  For all its size it serves no purpose.  It's just there -- like death -- hovering over a breathing city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Turn back into the picture.  Margarete pats Kafka sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His friends glance at each other surreptitiously and don't know what to say -- other than goodnight
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about your friend -- I'm sure he'll turn up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a parting word) What are you working on, Kafka?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm writing a story about a man who wakes up one morning to find himself transformed into a giant insect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Turns to go -- when he notices Bizzlebek leaning listlessly in the coffee house doorway.  A figure in the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka suspects he's being mocked.  But perhaps not. Bizzlebek steps out, buttoning his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's already quite proud of himself -- tossing his scarf over his shoulder with a flourish -- and striding off into the night.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've read your stories.  They're fantastic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not sure if he believes him) I don't know what you could have read.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just what you've published.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In magazines nobody reads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I read the one about the penal colony.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cautious) Did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The needles inscribing the judgement into the flesh of the man. (looks impressed) Very good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I could sculpt as well as that, I'd be quite proud of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Seen from just below, from the ancient cemetery that borders its high, impregnable, imperial walls.  The all-seeing-eye of the city.  An awesome edifice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka walking across from the Old Quarter toward the New Town. He passes some working-class types who seem vaguely threatening.  Do they mutter some remark behind his back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bizarre street.  Tiny little houses that look fashioned by a toymaker, all bunched tightly next to each other, forming a continuous rooftop of odd configurations and angles and pointed chimneys.  The street named after practitioners of the black arts and dark sciences who inhabited it in the Sixteenth Century. Kafka's house is toward the back, a light shining from the single upper window.  Through it, Kafka is seen sitting at the only desk that really matters to him -- his writing one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's struggling to get a sentence right -- rereading it to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly there's a loud KNOCK on the front door below.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from disturbing dreams he ... from unsettling dreams ... uneasy dreams ... Gregor Samsa ... Gregor ...?" (wondering) Carl.  George.  Rudolf ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka opens the tiny front door of this almost-miniature little house.  Two intimidating MEN stand outside, one tall, one short, wearing similar black suits and grim expressions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka tries to match the exacting pace of his two warders, flanking him as they walk him along a corridor, through another doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka tugs his collar up a bit, his breath visible in the air.  He has a feeling what's going to be under the sheet on the lonely trolley in the middle of the room before the first man summons him over to it. Kafka goes.  The first man yanks the sheet off the face in one quick movement.  The face of Eduard.  White and bloated, the tongue jutting, the eyes bulging. Kafka recoils, stepping back instinctively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now he hears a stirring in a dark corner.  He looks up again. A third man steps out of the shadows where he's been quietly standing and walks over to Kafka.  He is a severe man, stolid, dedicated, and never smiles.  He reminds Kafka of his father.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (still behind Kafka at the door) You know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His name is Eduard Raban?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with an introductory nod) Inspector Grubach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Inspector behind his big desk.  Kafka in front of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kafka -- is that your real name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.  Yes, of course -- why wouldn't it be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When was the last time you saw Mr. Raban?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wednesday.  We left the office together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you go anywhere afterwards -- to have a drink perhaps?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, we said goodbye outside the building.  He went off, as usual, toward his house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (consulting papers) Your office is the Workmen's -- KAFKA -- Accident and Compensation Association.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you've been employed for seven years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eight -- and seven months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Engaged in the manufacture and distribution of ... pills and so forth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- other departments are, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you describe your relationship with the dead man as close?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.  Since he came to the office, almost three years ago, we've been quite good friends. (pause) How was Eduard ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was found in the River.  Could he swim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was he depressed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  He didn't seem to be.  Do you think he drowned himself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grown men don't normally fall into the river, do they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I suppose not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (closing the file) He might have had a drink or two, despite what you think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as the interview seems to be over) Can I ask -- how you found me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His landlady knew of no other friends to refer us to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think he really had any. He had no family either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wasn't a lonely man, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What makes you think so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Just a perception.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes out of a door that closes behind him.  He stands and waits.  At a high desk a POLICEMAN is reading a newspaper.  Without even looking up from it he extends his arm and pushes Kafka slightly to one side so he's no longer blocking the light. Two other MEN are here waiting, sitting on a bench, sharing a private joke.  Kafka glances down at himself, wondering if his appearance could in any way inspire ridicule. The door opens again and the Inspector is back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods curtly at Kafka, and shuts his door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't usually involve myself with you people in the Old Quarter
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: but the River runs its own course. It won't be the last time it deposits its unwanted debris on my doorstep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, I'd like you to reflect that in me you have -- I won't say a friend, because we're complete fencers, of course -- from distinctly incompatible social classes -- but to some extent, shall we say, an interested third party.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bear that in mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hands Kafka his card)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should you happen upon anything that might be relevant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With Eduard's sheet-covered form on it, coming down the hall, the SQUEAKING WHEELS of the thing loud on the wooden floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The noise causes him to turn around.  He watches the trolley as it's pushed past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Similarly coffin-like, loaded with files.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edges out of the way to let it by, feeling as though it has been made for him, is waiting for him. He walks on to the Chief Clerk's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka does.  And the Chief Clerk stands up.  He paces up and down a bit, making Kafka awfully nervous before he finally clears his throat and starts to get to the point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chief Clerk, towering over him, also reminds Kafka of his father.  Kafka tries putting up a defense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka merely nods, starts to get up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka sits back down in the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka nods once, starts to go again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He returns to his paperwork.  Kafka leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You wanted to see me, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicates a chair) Sit down, Kafka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been with the firm for nearly nine years.  You've done your work diligently, there are no complaints on that score.  But there's more to the job than the work -- there are other people to consider -- and frankly, Kafka, we eel your social situation could bear improving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... My ... social situation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You keep too much to yourself -- you're a lone wolf.  It makes me uneasy, and if it makes me uneasy I can't imagine the impression you make on lesser employees.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To do my work well, I have little time for -- CHIEF CLERK You must make the time.  Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I usually take lunch by the River.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates.  At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did not realize it was obligatory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing -- (as he paces past and Kafka turns his head) why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Attitude, Kafka.  It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leans forward in rebuttal) Well, I -- CHIEF CLERK (keeps pacing) Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eduard -- CHIEF CLERK -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps.  He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having.  I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In any case -- don't ask me why -- the word has come down you're to be promoted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your colleague's death has helped precipitate the need, though I can tell you it's been under consideration for some time.  You're to be given two assistants and a commensurate rise in salary. (sits back behind desk) That's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kafka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand you fancy yourself an author.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost visibly cringes) In a small way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You might find a more athletic hobby -- put some color in your cheeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Walking away, Kafka notices Gabriela striding along an office corridor -- and sneaky Burgel confronting her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks distressed, walking tall as if to bolster her composure.  Sneaky Burgel does not help matters by characteristically appearing from the sidelines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, in a terrific release of pent-up emotion, she slaps him hard across the cheek, the first of what would be a flurry of blows if not for the fact that the unexpected force of it throws Burgel reeling backwards before she can deliver any more.  Instead she rushes away, very upset.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning -- (she ignores him) Or should I say good afternoon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say what you like -- no one pays the least attention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking quickly alongside her) Oh, don't they?  I think you underestimate my station in this office and overrate your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not today, Burgel.  Send one of your memos, write up one of your communiques, but for God's sake don't bother me today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my place to offer advice, not yours -- and by advising the Chief Clerk of your unpunctuality it's certainly not my situation that's compromised, if that's what you're implying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stops to glare at him) You're just doing your job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's what I'm paid to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're detestable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're late!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As startled as the rest of the office by the incident. Burgel recovers, straightening up in shock and embarrassment.  He immediately resolves to march directly to the office of the Chief Clerk. Seeing him coming, Kafka quickly starts away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAY OSKAR and LUDWIG.  They look almost the same.  At first glance almost identical.  It's only a closer inspection that shows them to be imperfect twins.  Dressed in matching suits. One is sitting on Kafka's new desk, the other in Kafka's new chair.  They're rummaging about in his papers, and whenever one selects a particular document for closer scrutiny, the other promptly snatches it out of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coming this way, has paused, having spotted the weird duo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Continue with their mischief until one of them notices Kafka coming and nudges the other so strongly he almost falls over.  They're both standing at attention, looking guilty, by the time Kafka arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka smiles at them, half in friendliness, half in amusement at their quirky appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oskar responds first, but Ludwig knocks his hand out of the way to get there first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka doesn't quite know what to make of these two, but they seem pleasant enough fellows and they're looking at him with such wide-eyed innocence he doesn't know what more to say to them.  So he turns to look around the new area he's been assigned -- a burrow all to himself now -- even a personal clothes peg on the wall for his coat. The Assistants make stupid faces at each other behind his back, but look serious again when he turns around.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My assistants, I presume.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- that's us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (offers his hand) I'm Kafka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking hands) Ludwig.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (now it's his turn) Oskar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look like brothers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- we do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you worked here long?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no -- quite a long time, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we'd better move things from my old desk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Look at each other with identical frowns, then back at Kafka.  Oskar nods, as if to say "oh, all right, if we must."  And Ludwig grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka types up forms.  He hears some noise and glances over his shoulder to see how the Assistants are getting on -- they're sharing another desk, facing each other, and seem to be working quietly, though with pouting expressions. Kafka rolls a new form into the typewriter -- when a shadow falls over the page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka looks up at her.  He nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eduard and I had lunch together one day ... and you saw us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the Embankment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka and Gabriela stroll by the River, Kafka finishing off his lunch as they go, occasionally offering tidbits to Gabriela who either samples or refuses them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka lets out a smile at that.  Gabriela is suspicious of smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gnarled, barren branches of a nearby tree shiver over the two of them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was having an affair with Eduard. (notes Kafka's reaction) He didn't tell you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He would have.  You were his best friend.  A better friend than me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suspected that he -- well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That he was -- satisfied in that regard.  I didn't want to pry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (throws her hair back proudly) It's not that we wanted to deceive anyone -- but you know how these things are looked upon at the office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This morning it was suggested to me that my own sense of office fellowship could bear improving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As long as it's on their terms. If your work and your private life don't correspond to their specifications you're labelled a dangerous agitator -- with no recourse whatsoever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long were you and Eduard -- GABRIELA Two or three months, that's all. (adds)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I seduced him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A flight of stone steps takes them up here to this vantage spot overlooking the River and the city beyond.  Kafka stands by a railing -- and the huge, distorted shadow of SOMEONE looms suddenly on the high wall under him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment she seems about to tell him, but then looks away.  Kafka follows her gaze.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know as well as I do that he didn't commit suicide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't.  I'm amazed that anyone is able to bear life with any assurance at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eduard didn't see it as something that needed bearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The police would know the difference, wouldn't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think people in the New Town care what happens over here? (nodding across the water) This will always be the ghetto.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wasn't robbed.  He was identified by his wallet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you believe everything the authorities tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I have no reason to doubt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The very fact that they're authorities should give you reason. People will do anything to protect their own interests.  For all you know he was killed at the hands of the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What could he have done to warrant that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Someone else has paused at the embankment wall further away to stare at the roiling water.  He's too far away to see clearly.  Probably nothing sinister about him at all. Still ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turns back to Kafka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eyes lock on his for a moment.  She's beautiful.  He's fearful.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you free tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are some people I'd like you to meet.  Can you come to the Musil district at eight o'clock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You almost married recently, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last year.  I -- it was broken off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eduard wanted to marry me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you ...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm suspicious of men who want to marry.  I believe they think it's the only thing that will make them equal to their fathers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Disappears, the ominous black mass flowing off the large flat surface as abruptly as it arrived.  While up there on the terrace we see Gabriela walk away from Kafka.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE SHADOW ON THE WALL BENEATH

direction.raw_text: Stays where he is a moment, watching her.  He may have found his ideal woman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (then follows behind her)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know the Musil district.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without turning) You won't have any trouble finding it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sit laughing, jowls gyrating, around a table filled with an abnormal amount of food.  One of them stops laughing then, and the others follow suit, one after the other in turn, until they're all silent, looking at the same thing. We're in a fancy restaurant, and the other customers have also turned away from their dinners for the moment to stare at the Man in Black who stands before the Fat Men. The man wears a black mask as well.  He presents the Fat Men with a covered tray.  They look at it, then back at him -- but he's walked away.  They look at the tray again -- and one of them lifts the cover.  Underneath lies the classic black bowling ball -- with a fuse burning at the top.  The Fat Men all try to stand up at once but -- BOOM!  Their booth explodes with them in it. At the doorway, holding a revolver loosely in one hand to discourage heroes, the Man in Black turns calmly to face the stunned restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves.  Fire in his wake.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hoarse voice) Long live anarchy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka walks the crooked streets -- in the direction of the plume of smoke and illumination coming from the burning restaurant. In the dark distance behind him there seems to be a person following him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neighborhood denizens have come out, hearing all the excitement not far away.  Kafka walks past.  He looks behind him, but the following figure has gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes around a curve -- and sees ahead a dark figure a black cape standing waiting under a lone lamppost.  When Kafka gets a bit nearer, the figure starts to walk slowly away, as if expecting Kafka to follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dark figure walks alongside a row of black window panes, turning around the corner where they end.  Kafka follows around the corner -- and through a dingy doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leads him up to a large attic.  Warning shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gloomy except for the light around a table at a far end. Kafka advances, seeing Gabriela sitting there with her same companions from the coffee house.  Kafka stops in front of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka turns to see the last of the group come in, having obviously tailed him all along.  A burly man with a BEARD. The leader of this anarchist cell. Kafka sits down, in between a SOLEMN man with a moustache and a woman with a POCKMARKED face.  The seedy YOUTH who led him in completes the circle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriela darts a fierce look at her overly-flippant colleague.  And Kafka is sad about his dead friend for a different reason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment's pause, Kafka stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka notices that the Bearded Anarchist has a tattoo on the back of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka sits down again.  He tries not to be distracted by the Solemn Anarchist who says nothing but who takes an uncommon interest in seeing how many matches there are in the matchbox he's been fiddling with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A skylight casts moonglow over the proceedings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Solemn Anarchist looks up from his matchbox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands to leave again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka starts walking away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka keeps on going, the anarchists growing smaller as they're left behind in their far corner of the long attic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll save the introductions. (takes his seat) We don't know yet if you're friend or foe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Strangers make better foes than friends.  Will you tell me who you are altogether, if not individually?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heralds of a new age -- does that sound immodest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could say we represent the un official view of a well-ordered society.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Gabriela) Ah -- we're back to the "authorities" you spoke of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're ubiquitous.  What we try to do ... is make them a little less so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite a disturbance tonight, yes? And perhaps you recall last month -- the explosion at the Municipal Courthouse that sent one of the examining magistrates to join the heavenly choir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disbelieving) ... Was Eduard one of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The last to join us, the first to leave us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Why take me into your confidence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's obvious, isn't it?  We have an opening for a new member.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I nominated you as a possible candidate.  You were Eduard's good friend.  He read me some of your work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've hardly published enough for anyone to draw conclusions from.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You strike me as a man with a defined notion of injustice -- a high concern for the lot of your fellow men.  And yet you're able to remain an outsider.  With the concomitant air of ... superiority?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In short, a higher man.  It's what we want.  It's what we need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The distance to my fellow man is for me quite a journey.  As for being an outsider, it's never been a matter of choice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Kafka starts to leave)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They may have instituted proceedings against you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turns) What proceedings?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Preliminary investigations may already be underway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were his friend.  One link is all they need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The day he died, Eduard was called up to the Castle.  Did you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head) What of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was summoned to help correct a minor discrepancy of some sort in the Medical Records Division. Apparently one of his claims was relevant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merely in the interests of order, you understand.  The officials at the Castle like to cover their tracks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was never seen alive again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you still maintain -- what? That he was murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As you can imagine, a pass into the Castle -- hardly ever granted -- was an opportunity we couldn't ignore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Castle represents every anachronism that needs to be destroyed if progress is to be made.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As you know, it's not the most accessible location.  Far from being depressed, Eduard was particularly excited when he brought us the news of this chance invitation. He set off that evening carrying one of our custom-made briefcases instead of his own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gauging Kafka's reaction) You're shocked at the thought of Eduard tossing a bomb through a window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no right to be, I know.  My experience with real life  is practically nil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you only see someone sitting at a desk all day, it's liable to create a false impression.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People must think the same of me -- a quiet, dependable person.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to accept everything as true, my friend.  You need only accept it as necessary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As the bomb never went off, we can only assume he was caught with it -- and summarily executed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merely in the interests of order.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The formality of a trial would be too costly for them.  They're beginning to understand that it's the ensuing news of our actions that incites support.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Propaganda of the dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Castle will deny he was there any longer than his business required. They're just file clerks up there.  No doubt he was handed over to the police with the utmost discretion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In any event, we've felt no repercussions as yet.  Eduard must not have talked.  You're the one they contacted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So that's who my foes are -- policemen and file clerks.  Law and order, you might say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think what we're doing is so wrong?  And what are you doing? Pursuing goodness?  For what?  To answer to some supreme tribunal?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My only concern is the human tribunal.  Isn't it yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- which is why "quiet, dependable people" have to take charge of their own lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the cost of others?  You accuse people of murder without trial -- apparently without irony.  Did you go to the Castle with Eduard? (apparently not) Then you have no idea what really might have happened that night at all -- even before or after he got there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your human tribunal will betray you.  Just as its members will be betrayed when they find no supreme one
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Join us, Kafka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's sheer folly for anyone to try to pull through alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Seeming to emanate from pitch blackness -- but then suddenly, fast, out of a tunnel under a bridge come running three terrified VAGRANTS, roused from slumber and scared out their wits by the ghastly, crazed CACKLING chasing after them, ECHOING under the arches. They're at the river's edge, all running wildly, slipping and stumbling, every man for himself, as they desperately try to escape from whatever madness is closing in behind them. Now from out of the tunnel appears their pursuer, seen only from the back, literally shaking with insane, involuntary, howling LAUGHTER.  A horrific human hyena, far further gone than the sad wretches he's cornered here on this foul, moss-covered ledge in the cold wind. Seeing him, the vagrants freeze in their various positions -- then turn in panic to flee again as he starts after them, moving like an animal, a killer predator, laughing horribly as he goes. The First Vagrant, propelled by fright, manages to make a stunning leap up a wall to grab onto some overhanging chains and pull himself up.  The Second Vagrant finds himself trapped at the edge of the ledge -- with the Laughing Man choosing him as the one to go after first.  He turns and jumps into the river.  The Laughing Man, face still unseen, turns toward the climbing vagrant instead -- who clambers over the top just in time as the Laughing Man's fingernails claw the moldy wall beneath him. The Third Vagrant has made it to some steps, and down them -- glancing back to see the Laughing Man coming after him -- to the small patch of muddy beach at the bottom, grey river water lapping at his ragged shoes.  He doesn't know what to do -- he doesn't know how to swim!  The Laughing Man is running down the steps now.  The Vagrant starts wading out into the water, crying out in fear as the HOWLS behind him come closer and closer -- he throws himself forward, splashing vainly -- and feels the Laughing Man grabbing his ankles, pulling him back. The Vagrant's screams join the Laughing Man's insane giggles as they thrash around violently in the water.  The Laughing Man drags the Vagrant back to the beach, then back up the Steps, the Vagrant struggling helplessly, his head banging from step to step, his hands flailing around but finding nothing to clutch onto, his screaming going unheeded in this lonely part of the sleeping city. The Laughing Man drags him on, back to the slippery ledge and along it, dragging the Vagrant on his back through a filthy sewer alongside the wall, the Vagrant's cries choked by the stagnant water, but continuing as the Laughing Man drags him back into the dark tunnel, under the bridge, the two of them disappearing into the blackness again, their combined
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: louder than ever as it ECHOES horribly around the damp stone, then dimming as they go deeper and further away, unseen, until the screaming and the laughter can no longer be distinguished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka walks toward his desk.  Nearing, he sees the Assistants laughing in lunacy between themselves.  They hush up immediately when they notice him, and are pretending to work when he arrives.  He watches them out of the corner of his eye as he arranges himself at his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this sign of sympathy they immediately scuttle their chairs closer to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He elbows Ludwig violently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka stands up, pleased for them in their innocence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Assistants look at each other, perplexed by this attitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stick-like figure of Kafka turns into the long center aisle, walking between the endless rows of busy desks.  He sidetracks, taking a shortcut along a narrower aisle toward the exit he's heading for.  Another clerk is coming the other way and they both at the same instant turn sideways to sidle efficiently by one another, an almost balletic maneuver, perfected after years of office experience, nothing more than a short breath of air passing between them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How was your evening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine -- terrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncovering his typewriter) What was the matter with it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Ludwig) He can't sit still.  Just when we arrive at a nightclub he wants to go to another one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kafka) You look tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Gabriela Rossman was here looking for you.  Do you know her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We saw her naked once -- didn't we.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Women are all you have on your mind!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She went to the roof to sunbathe one lunch hour -- we watched her changing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't realize you'd been here that long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean because it's been a while since there was a sunny day?  What a good detective you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They keep switching us from department to department.  He doesn't mind because he can't sit still.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We used to be in the supply section, carrying boxes of medicine about but we dropped too many of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not too bad working here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't think it's a horrible double life from which there is probably no escape but insanity?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling after him) You should be content, you know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka working his way toward Gabriela's desk -- but he stops before he gets to it, a familiar shiver running through him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Empty.  The chair pushed squarely under it.  The typewriter covered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stares at it -- then at the ermine Mr. Burgel who has once again popped up out of nowhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burgel bows sarcastically to hand Kafka an envelope.  Then chuckles spitefully, obviously knowing something Kafka does not.  He walks off, leaving Kafka uneasy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you looking for Gabriela Rossmann?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka bounds up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door to his room is open.  Kafka goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes in.  Gabriela is here, gathering up Eduard's belongings from drawers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's stuffed the last of the clothes into a small bag, goes to take the few other possessions from shelves and elsewhere. Kafka notices that he's standing by a dumbwaiter.   For lack of anything better to do he pulls the rope to bring it up. It's filled with more clothes.  Gabriela comes over with her bag, holding it out for him as Kafka puts the clothes in -- but not as many clothes as they thought.  Behind the bundle, hidden at the back, is a briefcase. Gabriela recognizes it.  Kafka sees her surprised reaction. He removes the case and carefully flips the latches.  Inside, a complex mechanism, wires connected to a clock -- and a clump of dynamite. Kafka just looks at it sadly.  He closes the case.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hardly glancing at him) I'm collecting Eduard's things. If there's anything you want, take it or I'll give it to charity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking her note from his pocket) Burgel gave me this -- what does it mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (now looks up) Burgel! -- I didn't leave it with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going closer) Why were you given notice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're not obliged to tell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It couldn't be for that incident with Burgel the other day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it could -- Burgel's been trying to get me thrown out as long as I can remember. He could've killed Eduard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't put it past him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It seems I knew Eduard a little bit, after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The ratty old concierge peeks up the stairs inquisitively. In the doorway of his room, a LODGER clips his fingernails at a little folding table, neatly lining them up.  The concierge turns and notices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slams the door on him then returns to her own apartment, slamming that door too.  The hallway is empty now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lodgers!  Not one of them thinks to spare me such spectacles!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gabriela turns to Kafka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's got his number.  He's so in awe of her he has to turn away -- looking out the room's small window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriela clears some more items off a mantelpiece with a sweeping gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Putting the bag down, Gabriela goes closer to Kafka, so close he almost cowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns away from him, reddening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka sees an opportunity to go to her, to try to calm her, to make a timid approach to this woman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You might think -- I thought so myself at first -- that Burgel's too insignificant to be dangerous. But that's the very reason to beware! It's the small men to watch out for
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: the ones who substitute method for character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs at her relentlessness) Now you've fallen into his trap. When he goes to bed at night Burgel dreams of inspiring as much fear in others as they inspire in him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's still easier for you to understand suicide, isn't it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That street down there -- I always used to call it the approach road for suicides.  It leads straight down to the bridge and the River.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Burgel hated Eduard.  And me.  I'm sure he knew about us -- and I'm sure it drove him mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Burgel doesn't like anybody!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He used to like me -- very much more than I liked him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's jealous, yes, but that jealous?  He's too cautious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course he is -- the Castle precincts are not the safest part of the city after dark.  People disappear up there regularly.   If you want to lie in wait for someone, that's the place to do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you're saying Eduard was lured there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puts away the last few books) How often does one of our clerks have business in the house of records?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard of it happening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Burgel is the bringer of messages, isn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Usually.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or what if there really was an error? -- I don't know what kind -- any kind that needed correcting -- and what if Burgel was responsible for it?  One mistake -- even a small one in a firm like ours -- it could cost him a promotion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First these nameless authorities were the root of all evil, now it's insignificant Burgel.  If indeed there was a mistake -- and a minor one at that -- you're suggesting someone went to a lot of trouble over something so trivial as to not matter at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What seems important to these people is not determined by the amount of work it entails -- you're far from understanding the authorities if you believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now Burgel's one of the authorities?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For all his big talk he is.  Does he really have access to the Directors of the firm as he always claims?  -- or only the Deputy Managers -- people of no importance whatsoever.  Someone ought to follow him for a change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't make any sense of it while you're upset.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But she breaks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes hold of him as if to shake some sense into him -- but really because she needs someone to hold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriela doesn't seem to be listening.  She's looking around. the little room, as if it's someone else she's holding ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her head against his, Kafka tentatively touches her hair and she pulls away, the spell broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She storms out, vehemently picking up her bag on the way out, and slamming the door quakingly behind her. Kafka is too astonished at her behavior to make a move for a moment, then he glances at the bomb-case she's left behind, then he goes out to the landing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Burgel is only there for one purpose -- to spy on the employees and report any and all indiscretions, real or imagined.  If he didn't send Eduard to the Castle, you can be damn sure he's in league with whoever greeted him there. (very upset now) All those bastards are in league with each other -- why can't you see that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... I don't see anything.  I see a message on its way to me -- with all the right answers.  Only it never arrives -- it's always just on its way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eduard ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your ignorance of the way things are here is so appalling that it makes my head spin to listen to you and compare what you say and have in mind with the real situation!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rushing down the stairs in anger, tearing open the door at the middle landing and slamming that one too once past it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Following her down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coming down the final flight of stairs, disappearing through the door at the bottom, slamming that one as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost caught up with her, coming down to the last door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes through the door from the stairs, out of breath, and stops.  He's too late.  The hallway is empty.  The front door at the end of it is shut.  He makes a face and a moment later starts to go back up.  Then stops again.  Turns.  Looks back at the front door.  ... The one he didn't hear slam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The front door opens and Kafka steps out.  He stands on  the stoop.  He looks up the street one way.  Deserted.  He looks down the street the other way.  Deserted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka leads the police Inspector back along the lodging house hallway.  The two subordinate policemen follow behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've come to the door to the stairs now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Inspector stares at him.  The two other policemen roll their eyes at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You said she was extremely upset. People who are extremely upset -- Kafka -- are given to disappearing in a hurry.  They go and calm down for a day or so and then they come back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that's just my point -- she was more than upset, she was livid. She slammed every door on her way downstairs -- except that one. (points at front door) I was just behind her and I didn't even hear that one shut -- not at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not what I call conclusive evidence of an abduction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If someone was waiting here in the hallway to spirit her away, wouldn't they have shut the door as quietly as possible?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka keeps his eye on the two policemen as they poke around, one of them getting close to the dumbwaiter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says it rather derisively, separating the syllables of the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The policeman at the dumbwaiter peers down the shaft -- but then moves on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He signals his men, time for them to go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why would someone want to kidnap this woman -- the name is Rossmann?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You told me to contact you if anything relevant came up -- Gabriela is relevant.  When I spoke to you before I didn't know she'd been seeing Eduard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's been noted.  But where does it lead us?  Unless you have something more to add.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's missing.  I went to her house and she hadn't returned there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She lost her job today.  Just between you and me, I'd probably go away and brood a bit myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two Policemen lead the way back down, the Inspector behind them, Kafka remaining on the top landing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two other policemen look at each other ominously.  The Inspector turns to them, giving them a look, and they go off down the stairs.  The Inspector plods back up to Kafka Like a stern parent. They confront each other, Kafka trying not to cringe too baldly.  Scary shadows around the bizarrely-angled stairway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People treat Kafka like a child.  And other people seem big to him anyway.  The Inspector leans his face very close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves Kafka alone on the top landing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (manages to blurt out) Maybe it's true then what she said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses) What did she say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That the police may have allegiance to something other than truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She didn't think Eduard committed suicide. (then) Any more than I do. (then) She was convinced of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to say something, and I hope it's quite clear because I won't be repeating it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't have to hunt for criminals. We're drawn towards them.  The guilty show us the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes in, looks around, doesn't see his friends anywhere.  But at the bar, at his usual perch, is Bizzlebek, the coffee house habituE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka turns and looks at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where are your friends?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good question. Who are my friends ... would also be of interest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bizzlebek sits listening to Kafka's tale of woe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka stares at men and women around the coffee house -- couples, holding hands, kissing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka shakes his head sadly.  He's obviously heard argument before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at a woman who reminds him slightly of Gabriela -- a sexy woman and the man with her treating her as a sexy woman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (staring into steaming coffee cup) Gabriela was right -- it's easier for me to understand suicide. I'm a practicing suicide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly mocking as ever)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In what sense?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bachelorhood is just the slow form.  The bachelor doesn't sew seeds.  Only the moment matters. The space he occupies grows smaller and smaller -- until the only space right for him is his coffin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These strange stories you write -- they come naturally, do they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naturally? -- that's not the word I would have chosen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seriously) Where do you get your ideas? (quickly) Only joking -- I'm just joking. (laughing) Let's go to a brothel then, Kafka, come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't got the energy.  I mean, I have to conserve my energy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you work in that hideous insurance office?  -- dealing with people who fall off ladders.  Now take me -- I make my living as a stone mason.  It's not my art -- but it's the tools of my art.  You could be -- a journalist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be even worse -- it would be a compromise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Success or nothing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- not even success.  My writing is not for making a living -- it's for living.  Not for other people, it's for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... I'm the exile.  Gabriela was right about that too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Being chased around a table by a big bearded man in flickering black-and-white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching, laughing.  A great sea of grinning teeth and teary eyes. Except one.  Kafka sits grimly alone near the back.  But suddenly he's not alone -- the Bearded Anarchist has sat down in front of him -- and now turns round, startlingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the Pockmarked Anarchist is suddenly sitting beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the Youthful Anarchist is behind him, thrusting his head suddenly forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Solemn Anarchist is on Kafka's other side -- but he just watches the movie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka's head keeps turning around as they speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Solemn Anarchist suddenly laughs -- probably at Charlie Chaplin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka's head is spinning -- and the Solemn Anarchist suddenly looks at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We have another theory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We may have attached too little importance to the reason Eduard was summoned to the Castle to begin with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To correct a small discrepancy, you may recall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, but what if it wasn't ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Small.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if it was a large discrepancy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yours is a very powerful and important firm -- it has a lot at stake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps Eduard was closer than he knew to discovering it and so had to be silenced.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or he was even more an innocent victim than that -- he was chosen to bear the blame if the crime was uncovered by anyone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The crime so scandalous that the poor young clerk committed suicide rather than own up to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's mad .
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, it's mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue
