dialogue.raw_text: You said so yourself the firm is large and powerful.  If the discrepancy really was something big, Eduard's responsibility would still have to be small.  No poor young clerk could find himself in such a fix.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic grunt) When a scapegoat is needed, my friend ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to know what he was working on at the time of his death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He worked on routine claims.  His visit to the Castle was probably as minor a mission as he said it was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you so aggressively unimaginative?  Eduard is no longer the only casualty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why haven't I been -- YOUTHFUL ANARCHIST -- Kidnapped or murdered?  Because your connection with Eduard was obvious and above board -- not as easily misconstrued.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not secretive, therefore not suspicious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriela, on the other hand, had made an enemy of this man Burgel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (head turning, exasperated) Oh, Burgel!  Gabriela was having an affair with Eduard.  They were both members of this group .  If any crime's been discovered and people are paying for it, I'd look to yourselves !
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The loyal civil servant.  I suppose you'll deny that shortchanging the workers to whom compensation is due is standard company policy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wouldn't surprise us if the discrepancy was between medicines sent and medicines received.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People die for such discrepancies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the hoarse voice of the restaurant bomber) We must have a look at Eduard's file. cut:
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka follows the KEEPER OF THE FILES along labyrinthine alleys between shelves packed with files.  Walls are obscured by columns of documents tied together, piled on top of each other.  There's Hardly room to move.  Stacks of files are everywhere, balancing precariously, even falling from time to time, from sheer Pressure in all directions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They turn down another row, walking further, turning again. Kafka keeps flinching as thick bundles of documents CRASH down around him, narrowly missing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Keeper of the Files is rifling through folders -- causing others to fall out onto Kafka who tries to catch them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Keeper of the files looks extremely displeased.  He pushes past Kafka, going back the way they've come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Documents come crashing down and we can't see Kafka and the Keeper anymore.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (vexed) "Raban" -- that'll be nearly at the back of the alphabet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It usually is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snaps at him) I'm not obliged to give you access, you know -- not without authorization -- but I'll make an exception this one time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (oblivious to the danger) I'm overworked as it is. (finds the right section) "Raban" did you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.  Isn't it there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses) Wait a minute.  "Raban?"  Where have I heard that name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's the clerk who died last week. From the insurance department
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (follows anxiously) What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would we keep files on dead employees?  All old files are sent up to the Castle.  Do you think we have room for two hundred years worth personnel records?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dodges another paper landslide) It's gone out so quickly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whenever an employee departs, shall we say, it's up to the head of his department to requisition his file, reassign any outstanding claims, and send it off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean my Chief has it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looks up from his desk and sticks his chin out, which is his way of asking Kafka what the hell he wants.  Kafka dares to come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chief Clerk has little time for such sentimentality.  He gives Kafka a little exasperated look before reaching down to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir -- I understand you have Eduard Raban's file.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder if I might look to see if there's an address for family
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I'd like to write to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a right hand desk drawer -- which Kafka notices -- and taking out a folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka nods a bit, wondering what to do now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chief Clerk watches him as he starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka reluctantly turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka nods once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chief Clerk looks at him with seemingly genuine misguided concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes back to his paperwork.  Kafka leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No -- just as I thought -- no entry for family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was there something else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I just -- I feel a sense of obligation.  He was my friend -- if I can be of any help -- closing his affairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting file away again) No, there's only one report to complete.  I'll be doing it myself and submitting it to the Castle today or tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as ingenuously as possible) I see -- it's just the Erlanger claim then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks up) The Orlac claim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, yes -- well -- thank you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kafka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're too sensitive.  Let your friend rest in peace. (returning to paperwork) I've known suicides.  Such a song- and-dance about nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka shuts the door behind him, breathes a sigh of relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking very annoyed, leading Kafka back through the stacks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If it was Accounts you wanted why did you ask for Employees?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Orlac is an account?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a factory in the northern mountains.  One of our best customers. (as they disappear around a corner) Without a proper request I'm not obliged to do this, you understand
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: but I'll make an exception on this one occasion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka glances nervously around as shelves CREAK threateningly under the weight of documents.  Up on a ladder, the Keeper of the Files finds the Orlac folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls it out -- with great difficulty.  The Orlac file is very, very thick.  Kafka prepares himself to catch it, but the Keeper of the Files manages to hand it down to him without serious injury.  Still, it's quite cumbersome and heavier than Kafka expects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka winces at that slur but says nothing about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka scowls, and follows the Keeper of the Files in silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: At least the account is current even if the employee isn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming down ladder) That place has so many accidents, it's a good thing the type of peasants who live up there don't seem to have any trouble propagating their race.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leafing through pages) All these in the last year?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must have read about it in the papers -- there was a terrible cave-in.  It wouldn't have been so bad, but even the Medical Officer for the district was killed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did read that.  They gave him a posthumous medal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Dr. Murnau was the bravest of men. He spent an entire career in those backwaters with no regard for personal gain.  A great loss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a particular document) This is the cross-reference of clerks who've worked on Orlac claims?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Is your friend's name among them? (Kafka shakes his head) Then he only worked on the one case. (taking file back again) Your Chief will send me the final summation when he's finished with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Once a file's been sent to the Caste, is it possible to recall it for review?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going back up ladder) Of course not.  Only by a Director of the firm.  Who'd want to let in all kinds of riff-raff off the streets?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What good are records if they're not open for public inspection?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stuffing file back in place) These laws have been with us for centuries -- how can you doubt them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if I petitioned one of the Directors?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming back down) You do not summon them -- they summon you -- and this, of course, hardly ever happens, if at all. The Directors are an eccentric lot and by nature cautious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do our records go to in the Castle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting to walk away) We're a medical firm, aren't we? They go to the Medical Records Section.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could always apply there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It so happens, my dear simple sir, that the Head of Medical Records at the Castle is one of the Directors of this firm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka works at his desk, finger tapping at an adding machine. He checks the office clock -- nearly the end of the day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One is sweeping the floor.  The other is scribbling at their desk.  His pen blotches his paper.  He has a fit and crumples it up and throws it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks over at the Chief Clerk's office -- sees him writing intently at his desk, pausing to turn on a lamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sweeping one bangs his knee against a desk and starts hopping about.  The pen of the other one leaks again.  He crumples up his new sheet and flings it away even more angrily than before.  Then he examines his pen, determines that the cap at the back is loose, and starts banging it on his desk in an attempt to tighten it -- while the other assistant keeps jumping around holding his hurt kneecap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glances over his shoulder at them, starts to say something -- but then notices Burgel, not far away, sometimes blocked by other employees, walking in the direction of the Chief Clerk's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one assistant has just fixed his pen when the other one, still hopping around, bumps into him, causing him to knock over a bottle of ink.  The two of them start shoving each other about. Kafka whirls around, can't ignore them any longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Assistants look at him, surprised at this outburst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oskar tries to lunge at Ludwig, but Kafka holds him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Assistants look at each other sheepishly.  Then smile at Kafka, submissively or mockingly, it's hard to tell.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you mind!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just trying to finish some work!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you've actually begun some?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing at Oskar)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just because he's done nothing today, he doesn't want me to show him up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My assistants!  You might as well have fallen from the sky for all the thought that was spent in choosing you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not our fault.  We're naturally nervous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And we're upset too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't make a simple statement without him taking issue with it
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should meet my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've been together too long.  His personality is overflowing into mine and vice versa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would you like to be in a horrible situation like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He wouldn't.  It's the nightmare of his life. But now he's distracted again -- noticing Burgel walking away from the Chief Clerk's office (without ever having seem him actually enter it).  And Burgel is carrying a parcel under his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Assistants do as they're told, Oskar returning to his desk to clear up, turning his back on Ludwig -- at which Ludwig  immediately rushes up very close behind him and shakes his fist strenuously at him, turning away quickly when Oskar turns around again to try and catch Ludwig at it. Kafka isn't paying them any attention anymore.  He efficiently cleans up his own space, keeping an eye on the Chief Clerk's office. When the office bell RINGS the Chief Clerk immediately turns off his desk lamp, puts on his overcoat, and shuts his office light on his way out. Kafka doesn't think twice.  He forces himself to start walking to the Chief Clerk's office.  Other departing office employees crisscross past him, but he walks in a straight line, businesslike, toward the Chief Clerk's office.  He has a piece of paper in his hand.  He enters the Chief Clerk's office, holds the paper out to drop on the Chief Clerk's desk
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Assistants again) All right, you might as well go home -- go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: but lets it slip off onto the floor.  When he bends to retrieve it he quickly opens that bottom drawer where Eduard's file was -- but it's now empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burgel walks along, adjusting the parcel under his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Following him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burgel heads into the Old Town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pauses in some shadows.  He glances up at the distance, the way Burgel is going, up at -- THE CASTLE Almost glowing as it's outlined against the blue of the darkening night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Giving Kafka the eye as he goes past doorway after doorway filled with their frightening/tempting forms.  But he tries never to lose focus on the small form of Burgel further up the street. Men milling about, up and down the street, prostitutes roaming amongst them, Kafka negotiating his way through.  An urgent moment when he almost loses Burgel -- then sees him turning down an alley.  Kafka hurries after him, avoiding a pair of drunken louts in the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Castle visible, but still a little in the distance. Kafka comes into view.  He sees Burgel entering a building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very dingy.  Burgel leaves the top of the stairs and walks down to a room at the end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka waits momentarily at the bottom, then goes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peeking around the corner, he sees a YOUNG GIRL embracing Burgel in her doorway before letting him in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes out of the building.  He hears a noise, turns around, sees Burgel and the girl on the tiny baroque balcony outside her room.  Kafka retreats into the shadows.  He watches the girl unwrap the parcel Burgel's given her.  She smiles as a box of chocolates is revealed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watches -- with an expression of guilt, sadness? Until a door suddenly opens at his back.  A MAN shuffles out past him.  A rather ugly WOMAN in a dressing gown holds the door open, giving Kafka a cursory look.  Beyond her inside, a quick glimpse of MASOCHIST yelping as he's whipped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's nodding him inside.  Kafka backs away from her and her invitation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what're you waiting for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka heads for the dilapidated building or the anarchists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes through.  A MOUSE scurries past him across the threshold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leads him up to the attic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watches Kafka's approach.  But sees nothing.  His eyes are wide open, but lifeless. Kafka stops at the anarchists' table.  They're all lying around it on the floor except for the Pockmarked Anarchist who's slumped over it, her face sunk in a pool of her own blood. The Youthful Anarchist lies on his back, mouth open, still dribbling red.  The Solemn Anarchist seems less than solemn due to the almost comic, convoluted, broken-backed position he's in.  And the neck of the Bearded Anarchist is all twisted. Kafka just stares in disbelief -- then SCRATCH! -- a noise from a spiral staircase close by, leading to the roof.  Kafka looks around in panic -- the attic entrance is too far to run to and there's nowhere else to hide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man appears from above (MR. PICK).  Legs draped in expensive trousers, the skirt of his high-buttoned coat flowing around them due to the breeze from the roof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his arm up to help down whoever it is he's talking to.  We hear a strange GROAN.  Followed by the appearance -- unclear, from the back, face hidden, or otherwise blocked by Mr. Pick -- of A STRANGE hunched figure.  He moves in a halting, cowering way.  Mr. Pick helps him down the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pick's voice is reassuring, though he has a dark, diabolic face.  They're at the bottom of the staircase now, Mr. Pick leading his odd companion toward the exit.  The odd companion lurches towards the dead anarchists, but Mr. Pick restrains him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . PICK'S VOICE -- Come on -- there's no one up there.  We're going now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PICK That's it -- it's all right -- you've done very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PICK Never mind them -- they'll be attended to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pretending to be one of the dead anarchists.  Hiding under the large body of the Bearded Anarchist.  Trying hard to emulate his lack of movement.  Blood from the Bearded Anarchist's ear drips onto Kafka's face.  He tries to blink it away while his other eye remains fixed on the two figures walking away to the doorway until they're through it and gone. After a moment, he unloads the Bearded Anarchist and softly hurries over to the attic doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Strange Man utters another low moan as Mr. Pick leads him like a dog down the creaking old steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Comes cautiously out onto the landing.  He leans over the bannister, watching the two figures slowly going down the long stairs, vanishing from sight at a certain turn of the staircase on every floor and coming into view after a moment or so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pick and the Strange One walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Follows at a respectable distance.  He pauses when he hears a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looking back at the anarchists' building to see it pulling up outside.  The DRIVER jumps to the ground. Kafka looks from the wagon to the two men walking away in the distance and makes his choice -- continuing after the two men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the outskirts of the city, beyond the Castle. Mr. Pick and the Strange Man approach.  Some distance behind them, Kafka takes cover behind a tree, watching. Mr. Pick leads the Strange Man down the central quarry to where a third man, a LABORER by the look of him, is waiting. Kafka finds a vantage point somewhere above the central quarry.  He flattens himself on the ground and peers over the edge. In the quarry, Mr. Pick steps back a pace from the Strange Man as they meet up with the Laborer and suddenly grabs the Strange Man, pinning his arms behind him, baring his chest or the Laborer to stab a dagger into! Kafka is shocked by the abruptness of this.  He sees the Strange Man slump to the ground.  He crawls a little closer. He sees the Laborer replace the knife in its sheath on his belt, then help Mr. Pick drag the Strange Man off to some side shadows where they dump him. Kafka strains forward a little, trying to make out their faces -- and the ground gives way!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PICK AND THE LABORER Spin around at the noise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lands at the bottom of the incline, dazed.  He's still quite far away from the other end of the quarry where they are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PICK AND THE LABORER Look at each other once -- then go after the intruder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sees them coming.  Scrambles to his feet.  It takes him a split second to establish his options.  Namely, the best route is back up the way he came.  If only he can get up it again as fast. Mr. Pick and the Laborer start to run. Kafka starts to climb.  The incline is steep.  The gravel is loose.  He slips back down. Mr. Pick and the Laborer are gaining speed. Kafka digs his fingers into the dirt, pulling himself up with all his might, even though his shoes don't sustain holds. Mr. Pick is a better runner than the burly Laborer.  He's almost there. Kafka slips back down again.  Mr. Pick could almost grab him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but Kafka literally throws himself up the slope again, gasping -- and Mr. Pick stretches but can't reach that far and Kafka's nearly at the top again -- Mr. Pick climbing after him now -- and Kafka's arm comes over the edge, he struggles over, kicking gravel back down in Mr. Pick's face. Mr. Pick slides back down to the bottom -- and Kafka's gone. The Laborer fell over Mr. Pick as he came crashing back down, now Mr. Pick pushes him off in one direction while he goes another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Escaping back into the Old Quarter, Kafka runs downhill.  But even the momentum doesn't carry him as fast as he'd like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A number of streets branching off.  Kafka sees Mr. Pick coming down one of them -- and the Laborer coming down another.  Kafka runs off along a third.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka runs.  Looks behind him.  Mr. Pick is coming.  He runs faster, under a weird archway.  Looks behind him.  Mr. Pick and the Laborer are coming.  Kafka darts down a side street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another twisting little road.  He winds around one corner only to be met by another, the end of this street impossible to determine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pick and the Laborer are catching up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turns another corner and finds himself at the bottom of an incredibly long flight of steps.  A staired street.  On and on and on.  He doesn't know if he can make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PICK AND THE LABORER Come around -- look at the steps -- look at each other.  They take deep breaths and start up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here they come, huffing and puffing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka comes out from behind an extravagantly designed iron gate grillwork.  He sneaks away, back the way he came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The body of the Strange Man lies face down where it was dropped. Kafka walks toward it, looking around nervously in case anyone's coming.  Someone is.  When he gets to the corpse he hears the sound of an approaching WAGON.  He crouches quickly by the body to do what he's come here to do -- turn it over to look at -- THE FACE Of a monster.  Horribly disfigured, scarred and stitched. And it isn't the kind of patchwork mess caused by acid or accident.  There seems to be design behind it.  Human design.  And beneath all this warped, mutilated flesh, almost unrecognizable ... the features of the vagrant snatched from the River.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Revulsion.  He goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parks above the quarry.  The evil-looking Driver jumps down and pulls a large sack off the back.  He starts down into the quarry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appears over another edge.  He looks over at the wagon.  He sees that now the back is loaded up, and covered by a sheet of tarpaulin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the bodies are gone.  Even the floorboards and pieces of furniture that might have had blood stains on them have been torn away and removed.  Kafka stands alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An eerie moon shines over the Castle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes in.  Before taking off his coat, he finds in a pocket Inspector Grubach's card.  But what can he do again without evidence?  He puts the card back in the pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits writing into the night in his little room under a low ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The BARKING of a DOG outside distracts him.  He stands up to stretch by his open window -- and we SEE that he's wearing a suit that's far too big for him, sleeves overhanging his skinny arms and  ands, trouser bottoms drowning his shoes. He looks out at the sky which is turning blue.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: oh, and thank you for the suit from Father, although I don't know why he didn't simply return it.  If it's too small for him why do you immediately suppose it will fit me? ... Your son ... Your loving son ... Your somewhat loving son ... Your occasionally loving son ... Your incapable-of-loving son ... Your absolutely-bored-to-death-with-any- kind-of-family-life son ..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two men walk across the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rolls along one of the moribund streets of the Old Town.  The Driver swivels in his seat, looking over his wide shoulder, as if to see if he's being followed.  The glint in his eye suggests Evil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka puts a stamp on his letter, then adds it to the stack of obsessive correspondence already piled on one corner of his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With an ink-pad stamp, Kafka POUNDS the date onto a succession of documents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Strikes six.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jump in unison when the BELL goes off.  Then in their hurry to leave start shoving all their papers and whatnots haphazardly into various drawers, opening and slamming them regardless of whether or not the contents are fully inside, resulting in a lot of crumpled documents and snapped pencils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly hovering by Kafka's side, handing him something.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Chief Clerk would like this ready for tomorrow morning. (oily) He says it should only take you an extra hour or two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dead silence after the daily racket of typewriters and telephones and adding machines.  Kafka works alone in the utterly deserted office building. He looks out the window and sees a POLICEMAN walking by on the street below.  He thinks again about going to the law -- but goes back to work. He hears a SOUND.  He looks around.  A sort of a SCRATCHING sound.  It's coming from the other end of the office somewhere.  Maybe the bathroom. Kafka walks slowly back there.  At the bathroom door he pauses momentarily, then turns the handle to go inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  Kafka looks for the source of the sound -- and in sudden startled shock instantly finds it -- where a huge arm has just been thrust through a small, high window -- and the ugly hand at the end of the arm is feeling around for the window-latch. Kafka starts backing away -- as the hand flips open the latch
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and now the window, swinging open with a bang, and the rest of the intruder starts coming into view -- out before all of him appears Kafka has run out and slammed the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka pulls a desk across the bathroom doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The MANIAC -- because that's what his posture and breathing, seen from the back, suggest -- lurches into the bathroom from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka grabs his coat -- and an umbrella off a rack.  He looks back at the bathroom -- the desk rocking back and forth as the intruder behind the door pushes.  Kafka runs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs to the elevator, sliding open the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !  The desk tips over as the bathroom door is forced open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka descending.  The elevator cranking slowly downwards. Then, nearing the ground floor, it slows down even further. Then it suddenly stops dead.  Kafka reaches for the walls to steady himself.  He looks through the gate, assessing the distance to the ground floor below.  He tries the gate but it won't open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks around the tiny space of the elevator.  The roof hatch.  He reaches up, pushes it open, starts to climb up -- and YAAHH! -- the Maniac's face appears in the opening!  It's another monster face -- this one even worse than the one Kafka uncovered at the quarries.  A groaning, drooling, misshapen lump of wrinkled tissue.  And its owner's arms now come through to stretch after Kafka. Kafka beats them back with the umbrella while still trying to pull the unyielding gate open.  The Maniac yelps as Kafka bashes the umbrella up at him, dodging his head out of the way each time the umbrella sweeps back at him, swinging his thick arms wildly to ward off blows and try and snatch the umbrella for himself.  He finally retreats under the barrage of blows and Kafka quickly takes the opportunity to lever open the gate with the umbrella. The Maniac's face reappears overhead.  Kafka stabs the umbrella up at him some more -- and the Maniac manages to grab it.  Kafka sits down on the elevator edge to jump down to the ground floor and -- THE MANIAC Lunges forward from above, scooping both arms down in a vain attempt to catch Kafka just as he drops out of sight -- landing on the ground floor with a roll. The Maniac HOWLS at his failure, his features even more horribly contorted, Practically filling the small opening of the roof hatch as he SHRIEKS.  And as his atrocious face comes CLOSER and CLOSER and CLOSER -- one of his eyeballs falls out! -- POP! -- out of the socket suddenly -- dangling into the elevator, hanging by a single sinewy bloody thread. The Maniac cries out and reaches for the eyeball, bringing it back up to try and stuff back in place ...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calls down there)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help!  HELP!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka runs away from the office building, in horror, off into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands at a corner, looking at his own house, scared even to go home.  But everything seems normal.  He starts walking there.  But when he reaches his front door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka turns.  One of the Assistants stands next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka turns the other way.  The other Assistant is on his other side.  Kafka looks between the two of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka might have expected this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the Assistants draws a revolver.  The other chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka starts walking the way a flick of the revolver indicates, the Assistants flanking him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you think you'd be safe back in your little burrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No matter how deep a hole you dig for yourself, the beast will always find you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're to take you to the Castle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So.  You're the guides up there. And we thought it was Burgel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They wouldn't let Burgel into the Castle.  You should look upon this as a great favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want any favors from the Castle -- just my rights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We answer directly to Ekman, the Senior Partner -- he practically runs the Castle.  In a case like this you're better off dealing with the highest authority -- even though it's equally futile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you speak to him you have to lean quite near his right ear because the left doesn't work so well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They head up in the direction of the Castle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the Assistants keeps making a show of wiping his brow, though it's by no means hot.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For all your incompetence I was beginning to think you were at least loyal to me.  You're very good ham actors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just doing our job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a farce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We think you'd better accept your position instead of pointlessly annoying us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What position?  Being prosecuted in a case like this means having already lost it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still, we're probably closer to you at the moment than any of your fellow human beings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close only by virtue of antithesis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka walks stiffly between the Assistants, the three of them almost locked together as one unit, like lifeless matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka suddenly points at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Assistants immediately bend their heads to look -- and Kafka bangs them together as hard as he can. The Assistants sit on the ground in a stupefied daze while Kafka's running footsteps echo around the dark street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) My assistants.  I should have known. Nothing is given to me.  I have to acquire everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) It's all right to be sarcastic in private to us -- because we have a sense of humor -- but when we're up at the Castle we suggest you don't make a fuss.  It would spoil the not unfavorable impression you make in other respects.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frankly, we don't understand why you've even bothered pursuing this business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It would be more accurate to say that it has pursued me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But your goal is so hard to reach. Do you think the official network would surrender to one man?  We would never think of attempting anything remotely as difficult.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My mother used to tell us of the young man who decided to ride to the next village and how she was afraid that -- not even mentioning accidents -- the span of a normal happy life might fall far short of the time needed for such a trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've dropped some money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bizzlebek, perched on his usual stool, turns to see Kafka at his side.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You work in the cemetery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man must eat -- (raises glass) And drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Castle cemetery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ancient tombstones crumbling with age, slanting out of the ground at bizarre angles, and cluttered so close together that a way can scarcely be made between them. Bizzlebek leads Kafka along the crooked little pathways, overgrown with crawling weeds, upwards towards the high section of the cemetery under the dark wall of the Castle. Bizzlebek, who knows his way around, seems more cheerful here than we've seen him before.  Kafka more fearful.  Wind
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  Leaves RUSTLE.  CREAKING trees cast ghastly shadows.  Scary tombs, all shapes and sizes, strange symbolic symbols on them, mystical figures and designs. Trying to keep up with Bizzlebek, Kafka spots a horrendous shape looming ahead of him.  He starts to bypass it -- and jumps when a tall plant brushes against him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The awful dark shape turns out to be no more than a particularly large tombstone, crumbled in places to give it an animal-like suggestion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He keeps walking -- and we SEE that he's carrying the bomb- briefcase he found at Eduard's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A BIRD rapidly swoops down from a tree, zipping past Kafka's head with a shrieking SQUAWK!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (waits for Kafka) Are you sure you wouldn't prefer going through official channels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Official channels -- a lot of good they've done me.  My only hope is to approach the officials personally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm flattered, of course, to be considered a friend -- even without knowing all the details. (Kafka doesn't take that cue)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To see such determination is reward enough for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Kafka men are famous for it, you know.  Delivering meat barefoot in the depths of winter, picking up sacks of flour with their teeth --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gulp)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, determination runs in the family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is one thing I'd like you to tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm trying to find things out myself
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: that's the whole point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What made you think I'd be able to get you into the Castle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The cemetery is nearer the Castle than anywhere else -- wasn't it part of the Castle originally?  -- I always assumed there'd be a gate or something. (stops again, concerned) Isn't there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a manner of speaking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They're at the graves at the very back of the cemetery, right up against the bottom of the Castle wall that stretches high above them into the black sky of night. Trees quiver around them.  Shadows dance.  Bizzlebek pauses at a particular grave, apart from the others, more hidden by overgrowth.  He runs his fingertips over the old, strangely lettered inscription.  He looks around the graveyard, making sure they're alone, then he moves to one side of the stone and leans his weight against it, pushing.  It shifts and slides open, uncovering the hole that lies beneath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Having lit the lantern he's brought with him, he holds it over the dark hole -- revealing a shaft and the rungs of a ladder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was restoring some stones here in the upper section one day -- and I found this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unclear) An empty tomb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A cenotaph -- a monument to someone whose remains ended up elsewhere. But look --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Castle gates were blockaded in the time of the great plague -- it's an escape route. (offers Kafka the lantern) Don't get stuck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (accepts it) Not a chance.  I'm the thinnest person I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka starts to climb down, shoes loud on the rungs affixed to the stone wall of this well.  But then he remembers something, pops back up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You appreciate my writing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taken aback) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you do me a favor then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I don't see you later -- go to my house and find my notebooks -- and destroy them.  All my manuscripts -- just burn them. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What an extraordinary request!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my last and final one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then its authority is in doubt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A true friend would do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not necessarily. (a pointed look) A wife would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A stooping Kafka makes his way along this gloomy underground artery, the lantern lighting the way. He comes to the end of it and what appears to be a little door.  He bends low to listen at it -- then unlocks the latch.  He pushes -- and the door moves forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka stands up -- and he's inside a big filing cabinet drawer . He steps out of it and looks around.  He's in an entire room full of file cabinet drawers.  A morgue of file cabinet drawers.  He shuts the one he came out of before walking away.  "D-7" says the label on the outside of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka makes his way through the shadows down here in the underground depths of the Castle.  A fiery glow and noise comes from an archway ahead of him.  When he gets to it and looks through he sees a sweating STOKER shoveling coal into a giant furnace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sudden door SLAM.  Kafka dodges back around a corner.  He
direction.name: direction

result.heading: NEAR THE END OF A THIN PASSAGEWAY

direction.raw_text: :  the quick cry of a man's agony, a scuffle of shoes on hard stone floor, a dull thud, a wave of peculiar shouts, running footsteps, more mumbled mingled voices -- which soon die out, leaving silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka walks slowly, straining his neck a bit in expectation of whatever lies ahead. The passage brings him to a row of dungeon cells.  A line of doors with a barred window in each.  One of them isn't closed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and lying across the threshold is the Laborer who chased Kafka from the quarries the other night.  The knife is gone from his sheath and his scull is caved in, a wooden stool lying on the floor beside him.  At the other end of the row of cells another door swings open at the top of a few steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fingers spear through the bars of another cell to touch Kafka!  A GAUNT MAN inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka dropped his lantern in surprise, and shrinks back,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've killed him!  Like a dog!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The inhabitants of the other cells start RATTLING their bars and beseeching Kafka.  He looks around, bewildered and horrified.  Hideous faces looking back at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shuddering, Kafka is moving away, making it through the shocking gauntlet, toward the door at the other end.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They won't like that.  Not a bit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll incriminate the rest of us! Let me out too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help us! -- release us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling above the din) You're in the bowels now, my friend! You've thrown yourself in it now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: who may have had his tongue cut out gestures desperately at a lever on the wall to unlock the cells. Kafka starts to tentatively reach for it -- when there's a sudden SHRIEK beside him.  He whirls to see, behind more bars, the raving, convoluted face of the creature that stalked him at his office (whose loose eye has now gone completely) -- BANGING violently against his door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But now the evil Mr. Pick appears at the end of the passage from which Kafka came -- a gun in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka yanks the lever and runs away.  Mr. Pick FIRES after him, starting to chase -- but the prisoners are coming out of their cells -- coming for him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let me out -- I'm all right -- they haven't treated me yet!  We can go together!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PICK You !
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka runs upwards, around and around and around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here is a part of the Castle Kafka can understand -- office workers toiling away.  Kafka walks past one long row of them,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sitting at a single endless desk.  They look like students under examination, hunched over their writing, a virtual conveyor belt of paperwork. In the center of this floor is an actual conveyor -- a chain pulley running slowly up and down, presumably throughout the entire Castle, through small holes in the floor and ceiling. There are little pockets on the chain which the clerks continually pluck papers out of and slip papers into. The ink bottle of one of the scribes runs dry.  He takes it over to a sink with three taps -- Hot, Cold -- and the third one he turns -- Ink .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka passes a FRIENDLY CLERK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka nearly laughs at the enormity of the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you lost?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm, uh, looking for the Medical Records Section.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you're miles away.  From here you'll want to go left, left again, right, right again, left then right, right then left, and take the Blue Staircase.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going on his way)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't seen you here before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He stands there, a man in a suit with a briefcase in an antiseptic corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ... I'm new.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pick leans against a door, trying to keep back the howling horde of prisoners pushing from the other side. Another JAILER joins him, helping him to try and push the door closed.  Then a SECOND JAILER too.  A bestial hand reaches through and Mr. Pick presses his pistol muzzle into the outstretched palm -- BANG!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A book falls to the floor like a pistol-shot -- and Kafka hides back in shadows hoping no one heard.  He's in a round -- LIBRARY -- Surrounded by books from floor to ceiling, even on the tall door through which he entered.  A sliver of light gives it away -- and on the other side of it he hears FOOTSTEPS. But they pass by. There's another sliver of light indicating another door in the books opposite him.  He walks over and pulls on the shelves.  Here the dark wood is merely a disguising cover for the shiny modern steel he discovers on the other side of it And he finds more than that as he enters -- THE LABORATORY A real mad scientist's workshop.  Chemicals of bizarre colors rush and FIZZ through mazes of glass pipes and beakers, in some places boiling and steaming, in others frosting or freezing.  Circuits and test tubes flash and glow as sparks and filamentary arcs CRACKLE with electric incandescence. insane instruments and devices, interconnected with complex wires, perform strange and villainous functions.  It's the most modern setting we've yet seen -- but at the same time all this futuristic technology seems somehow archaic, as if put together from old, familiar materials and elements, both eccentric and eclectic. The chain that runs through the floors of the Castle carrying documents runs up and down through the laboratory too. Amidst this feast for the eyes, what Kafka now focuses in on a simple cigarette -- left smoking in an ashtray.  And by the look of the ash, not very long ago.  Kafka looks around anxiously -- notices an archway leading to another room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr  Pick and the two Jailers can't hold back the dreadful prisoners any longer.  Mr. Pick runs, letting the Jailers fend for themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SMALLER ROOM Kafka comes into what looks like a small museum -- vertical glass cases in which naked BODIES float suspended in preserving gelatin solution. Kafka seems deadened himself by all that he's seeing -- until he sees someone he recognizes.  The Bearded Anarchist.  Kafka goes closer.  Looking down, he sees that the Bearded Anarchist has a hand missing.  The other anarchists are here in glass cases too.  Now with a gasp Kafka turns around -- looking for Gabriela -- but she's not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holding himself together, and with new determination etched on his face, Kafka walks to the center of the lab -- and an operating table.  Ignoring the implications of the table, he sets down the bomb-briefcase -- flicking the latches to open it. The sight of the explosive mechanism inside causes him a moment's hesitation, but a look round at various animal parts hanging from hooks above the table or bobbing in jars alongside sinister implements laid out in preparation for an operation renews his anger -- and he decisively turns the dial on the bomb's timer-clock, setting it to the maximum allowance of one hour. He closes the case and locks its latches.  The case begins to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Kafka takes it to a dark spot beneath the mass of elaborate laboratory equipment, hides it under there, and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka tries finding his way back the way he came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka looks down a long dark staircase -- a hint of light glowing at the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just as he reaches the light something lunges at him from one side!  It's the Laughing Man, hysterical as ever, face now
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: for the first time, SCREECHING, salivating, eyes watering.  The human hyena.  His grin contorts his face from ear to ear, his CACKLING is truly terrifying, and the hand he stretches forward has a tattoo on it (Bearded Anarchist's hand) -- a hand too big for his wrist -- reaching, reaching, reaching for Kafka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Laughing Man pushes Kafka down into a chair and shakes with uncontrollable sobbing shrieks. Someone else is sitting in darkness behind a huge desk (MURNAU).  His hand holds out a small vial.  The Laughing Man grabs it and leaves, gulping down its contents voraciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka tries to see into the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door behind Kafka opens again and an officious bureaucrat (EKMAN) comes in.  He sits in a chair and looks at Kafka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he's stood up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's coming around the desk.  He's drying his hands on a towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses the towel onto the desk.  Ekman looks irritated by this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He places a fatherly hand on Kafka's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he's an impressive, imposing figure of authority himself.  You'd probably trust him.  You'd certainly respect him.  But if you look into his eyes, he's frightening.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I assume you're wondering ... what all this has been about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you the Head of Medical Records?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Ekman) He's come on his own initiative. (to Kafka)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not something we encourage, mind you, but we like to know it exists.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What it amounts to is simply this ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A piece of paper was delivered to the wrong clerk.  It was essential he bring it back to us.  These complications have arisen because he had friends -- like you, among others -- friends unlikely to let a sleeping dog lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... A piece of paper ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A mere slip. (coming forward) Your friend Mr. Raban dealt only with claims that came in , another department being responsible for compensation that goes out -- this is correct?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not quite in the light yet) Through a very unfortunate -- and I might add extremely rare -- mishap, a document intended for the one department was sent to the other.  And for the first time -- though your friend wasn't aware of it -- two and two could have been put together to make one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (again) ... A piece of paper ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (face bending into the light) You see, Kafka, in all cases relating to the factory at Orlac -- which is what this paper referred to -- the authority that puts in a request and the authority that grants it is, to all intents and purposes, the same authority.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pick runs from the crazed prisoners chasing him.  Fires his gun back at them, dropping one or two -- but then runs out of bullets. The prisoners slowly surround him.  He backs away.  One of those chains that run throughout the Castle has its base here.  Mr. Pick keeps backing up, unavoidably, the deranged prisoners closing in -- until he falls backwards with a cry into the grinding wheels of the chain-system. Caught up in the chain, he's carried aloft with it, up to the ceiling.  The chain is the lifeline of the Castle and does not, could not, ever stop.  Instead it forces Mr. Pick to go along with it, his head CRACKING through the glass or wood "manhole" cover through which the chain passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka tries not to flinch in the presence of this deadly figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ekman sighs -- as if at a difficult child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ekman, who doesn't hear very well, directs one ear in particular back and forth between the other two.  Kafka just keeps looking at the charismatic man pacing around him -- who's now lighting an expensive cigarette of the kind that was in the ashtray at the lab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murnau laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You seem amused.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It only amuses me in that it gives me an insight into the ludicrous bungling that in some circumstances may decide the life of a human being.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's merely a matter of expediency.  It's imperative that my room to maneuver not be hindered by ... bureaucratic ramifications.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If an obscure official up there in the distant mountains so far away from civilizing influences happens to meet with an unfortunate accident
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and should he tragically die in spite of the District Medical Officer's strenuous efforts to save him -- the firm wants to see the next of kin pacified and the disposition of the remains handled with the greatest possible ... efficiency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (becoming clearer) "Accident and Compensation" -- no one can accuse the firm of not supplying exactly what it promises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Ekman) I believe we've exceeded his expectations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (virtually to himself) I had the grandest of financial plots in mind, the most malevolent of personal motives, conspiracy theories extending to every ... authority I could see. (looks up) And I find you.  A body snatcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Life is more than a Chinese puzzle, my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Uniformly, like a chorus line, the infinite row of clerks turn their heads from their single endless desk when they hear an awful NOISE: Mr. Pick is breaking through from the floor below.  The inexorably rising chain has hauled him floor by floor through the Castle, breaking open holes too small for his body, shredding him along the way, and still carrying him upwards ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka walks along with Murnau and Ekman.  The Laughing Man holds Kafka's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pass another of those grinding chains carrying memos and inter-office directives up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Laughing Man giggles crazily.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And I suppose Dr. Murnau didn't die in a cave-in.  You killed him to free the Position of Orlac Medical Officer for your own ends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well -- we're looking for a new village now.  If we stay too long at one source ... people become suspicious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you're quite right that he didn't die in that cave-in. In fact, he didn't die at all. He was simply recalled -- by himself.  As well as being Head of Medical Records here and a Director of your firm -- I'm Dr. Murnau, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Laughing Man, subdued for a moment, merely smiles a little, opening the door to let Kafka in first, guarding him close.  Dr. Murnau then leads the way across to his laboratory door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murnau laughs, but then has to stop as it encourages the Laughing Man, bringing forth a mad chuckle or two from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes the tall door open into his lab.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: May I ask where your two warders are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lying in the gutter where they belong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pity.  They're an amusing pair, didn't you find?  Absolute innocents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Murnau spreads his hands proudly as they enter, displaying his amazing factory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ekman, who's seen it all before, goes to lean somewhere, bored.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As if in response to that the Laughing Man convulses anew. Ekman immediately turns to a shelf for another vial and goes to give it to the Laughing Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Laughing Man gulps down the potion and starts to calm down a little.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I so rarely get the chance of showing my work to anybody -- anybody capable of appreciating it, that is.  You might say I'm a student of human reaction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fact that it's live bodies you practice your trade on doesn't seem to matter to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the contrary, it matters a great deal.  We're engaged in immensely important research here.  I'm a revolutionary too, you know -- but a much more pragmatic one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't very well administer experimental treatments to corpses -- and if they become corpses, why, they have their uses too -- that's why speed is essential.  Living tissue, even if its owner has passed on, is our most valuable acquisition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've tried transfusions on our ... volunteers.  Unfortunately, far from infusing superior characteristics it's tended to make them insane -- murderous even -- a condition we've had occasion to make use of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: lightly away.  The clock inside the bomb-case, becoming visible as if by X-Ray, is SEEN to be a matter of minutes away from blast-off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murnau walks to where the elaborate distillation processes are going on.  The very section where Kafka hid the bomb. Kafka wipes his brow, quickly, conscious of Ekman staring at him.  Murnau gazes obsessively at his contraptions, his piercing eyes following the routes of the flowing chemicals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's concocting another potion now, pouring an acidic-looking liquid from one container to another.  Kafka is looking increasingly worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at the dangling animal parts.  And now, finished mixing his cocktail, he picks up some sort of suturing tool, pressing the trigger on it to start the end burning and
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And the new patients they bring me aren't usually as dexterous as you've been in evading us.  Not perfect specimens by any means, but not the type of person who'll be missed either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What have you done with Gabriela Rossmann?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As a matter of fact you've caught us in a state of considerable excitement.  Our latest preparation we believe
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: we pray -- is perfected. It should take years off her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And if not -- well, there are always what I call my caprices of vivisection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ekman takes Kafka by the arm to lead him toward the operating table.  The Laughing Man moves in closer too, emitting a psychotic chortle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka attempts an escape around the operating table, but the Laughing Man blocks his way and corrals him back to where he was before.  Dr. Murnau holds out the sinister aperitif for Kafka to take and drink in toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The glass comes closer and closer to Kafka's lips -- if he leans away from it any further he'll be lying on the operating table -- but now a WRENCHING noise makes everybody turn. The body of Mr. Pick, bloody and ragged, is dragged up with a
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, if it weren't for the aberrant dilemma posed by someone like yourself -- continually asking for out-of-date files -- I'd probably give up my revisionist policies altogether. I'm sure what we have to do is start instead at the very inception -- with the embryo -- from a single cell even. (leers at Kafka) The lure of the Golem -- the man-made man.  You appreciate that, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To corrupt the image of man and then offer redemption ... This is the dawn, Kafka.  A new man is being born here.  A more resilient man ... A superman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To a new world -- of Gods and monsters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: through a breaking floor-panel by the great chain. Kafka has his chance.  The next time anyone looks at him he's holding the nozzle of the burning device under Ekman's throat, finger on the trigger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And on the other side of the laboratory a wide elevator platform rises into view -- carrying the prisoners from the dungeons!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throws Ekman aside and runs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Falls to the floor, holding his hands up over his head with a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the ghastly creatures from the depths converge on him -- but they pass him by -- intent on getting Murnau. The last out of the elevator is the most horrible BEAST-MAN yet -- and we finally see the use to which various animal-parts have been put.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just stands by the operating table, waiting for them.  He knows there's no way out and he's far too practical a man to waste energy running or screaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka running through the Castle, through door after door after door after door, leaving them all banging behind him, back and forth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ekman stumbles to his feet, watching in horror as the prisoners of the Castle strap Murnau to his own operating table. One by one, the prisoners file past the intricate surgical tools neatly laid out on white cloth.  Each prisoner selects the implement of his choice. Ekman, too, runs away out of the laboratory. The Laughing Man, snickering, isn't sure whose side he's on. But then, LAUGHTER BUILDING, he goes to join the others in line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka still running in the maze -- through a final door.  And he finds himself right back in -- THE LIBRARY With the brightness of the laboratory facing him through its open door.  Horrible SOUNDS coming from in there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Running again, through the maze of corridors.  He HEARS running footsteps behind him -- looks back to see Ekman running after him.  Ekman catches up -- but runs past Kafka in his panic to escape -- out onto a metal walkway around a central area of offices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murnau can't be seen, only the deranged men huddled closely around the operating table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abruptly stops ticking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The floors SHUDDER as the BOOM in the laboratory is heard and felt.  The metal walkway breaks and Ekman goes sliding off it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: while Kafka manages to hang on.  He ducks his face down as glass from all the surrounding office windows SHATTERS and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and then paper starts sailing down all around. Literally a hailstorm of documents. On the floor below where he fell, Ekman tries to stand, but the falling flurry of paper keeps him at bay.  He waves his hands wildly trying to see his way through it all, but it's too much.  Now his feet are trapped in it.  It's starting to rise around his legs.  Papers are fluttering down from floors and floors of surrounding offices above, filling the air. Ekman suffocates and drowns and disappears in the paper piling up around him -- one lone arm and hand the last we see of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Totally wrecked -- and jutting out of the broken walls are burst pipes -- spurting red, blue, and black INK everywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka is managing to climb back onto the unsafe metal walkway
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: when ZING! -- a bullet ricochets near him. The Assistants!  They've nearly fallen through another doorway where the walkway on that side broke, but got each other stuck in the door just in time.  One of them is wildly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a revolver in Kafka's direction.  The other tries to grab it and both FIRE it together in all directions. Kafka runs away, avoiding a snake of broken wire, flipping about, SPARKING off the metal. The Assistants, shoving each other, extricate themselves back through their doorway to find another way to chase Kafka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The burst ink pipes drip empty.  The sound of maniacal
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: abruptly stops.  The ink has filled the lab halfway to the ceiling.  It's covered everything and every ... body. A last bubble pops, leaving a lake of ink with a surface smooth as glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka has found his way back here -- rushing in.  But wait: Which file cabinet did he come out of?  He's surrounded by file cabinet drawers all alike.  He starts running around, pulling open drawers, trying to find the secret doorway through one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here come the Assistants, running round and round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka runs round and round, opening drawer after drawer.  He finds the one!  Jumps in!  Pulling it closed after him just as -- -- the Assistants stumble in.  They look at each other, then immediately start rushing around opening drawers.  They run back and forth and all around, bumping into each other, making themselves dizzy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (pulls open a drawer) Oskar!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning from another) Ludwig?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But Ludwig just pulls out a file folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start trading files back and forth, trying to put the system back in order.  The attention span of squirrels, they've forgotten all about looking for Kafka.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is filed incorrectly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here too!  They're all in a dreadful muddle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Opening.  The police Inspector enters the main courtyard. Behind him come the two secondary policemen.  Behind them, obscurely, a few more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and his men pause, reacting ... ... as the few wretched survivors of the Castle prison stagger out of the shadows to greet them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the Old Town side of the River.  Foggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walks slowly, tiredly.  He looks up at the sky, but the sky is a silver shield against anyone who looks for help from it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka stops.  Turns.  Did he hear something other than the wind and the water?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He passes through a small park, approaching a gate on the other side of it.  Leaves RUSTLING.  Mist swirling around him.  He opens the gate and -- BOO!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Standing there, half in shadow, in profile.  Her glorious profile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka is beginning to sense something quite wrong with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka just watches her ... The breeze sings in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka doesn't answer.  She turns fully to him.  The other side of her beautiful face is ... fungus.  Alive.  Seething. Frothing.  Bubbling.  Kafka backs away a couple of steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kafka starts to back away some more.  Gabriela starts to follow him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And suddenly she's slashed a knife across Kafka's chest.  He shouts in pain, staggering backwards.  She comes after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes after him, blade glistening.  Kafka does his best to run.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriela! -- you did get away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you walked this way to work.  I wanted to find you before they did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've just come from the Castle.  It's over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (her eye glancing far away) Over?  It's only over when you can crawl to a clean little spot on earth where the sun sometimes shines and you can warm yourself a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriela ...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I tell you why I joined our late lamented nihilists? Why I became a murderer? Because murder ... is bliss. (looks at him) It's easier than you might think to absorb and assimilate Evil -- once you've adopted its procedure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you ever watched a person deteriorate?  Day by day.  I don't mean in a spiritual sense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only two steps back?  Even the man they left to guard me retreated further than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I found your jailer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is the result of their elixir of youth.  They were to come and check on it during the night.  I contrived to miss the appointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're dead now.  We can get help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know how they reward failure. If they saw this I'd be rotting in the quarries by the afternoon
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: with all the others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a new potion -- he said it was perfected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know there is.  And you're what I have to bargain with. For now you're the last one in their way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you, they're dead .  It's finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I believe a man who never believed me?  They're absolutely right, you know -- guilt should never be doubted. It's easier that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you've just escaped for the moment.  Just as I did.  As Eduard did.  As they let us do. But only for the moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- not this time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know better than you what people will say when they have to.  When they brought me in for questioning I informed on my friends the very first day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me -- GABRIELA I do.  Always.  You understand the world better than any of us, Kafka.  And what it's becoming. (pause) I've always held you in the highest regard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriela!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kafka giddily staggers forward, one arm wrapped around his bleeding chest, Gabriela close behind him.  Too close for him to get away.  He turns to face her as he reaches the bridge and as she comes upon him again with the knife, raising his arm to block the thrust and hold her wrist back.  She's strong, though, made more so by her madness.  She forces him down to the ground, straddling him, the knife pushing closer.  Kafka gasps in pain, finally succumbs, no longer able to hold his hand up in defense, simply shutting his eyes with a terrible sigh to await the fatal stab. It doesn't come.  Almost.  But not quite.  Gabriela's arm pauses, shaking in the cool, cloudy air, her sleeve trembling in the breeze off the River, the sharp blade, inches from Kafka's throat, flashing in the new day's light. Gabriela stares away over the River, the destroyed half of her face in shadow again, the other more strikingly beautiful than ever.  As Kafka watches, passive, she gets off him and slowly walks to the wall of the bridge, letting the knife drop from her hand along the way.  Kafka manages to lift himself to his knees, clutching his wound.  He looks up. Gabriela in one graceful movement climbs over the wall and throws herself into the River. Kafka lowers his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quiet in here.  Breakfast business not as crowded as evening.  Kafka sits alone at  his usual table.  Looking dazed, almost in shock.  Mostly just tired.  Waiting.  He sips from his coffee cup.  He COUGHS a little into his napkin
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and notices blood on it. He has a pen in his hand.  Tapping it slowly on a newspaper on the table ... Bizzlebek comes into the coffee house.  He sees Kafka sitting in the far corner and gives a grand smile and wave.  But then he notices Kafka's other friends entering and he'd rather not have to deal with them -- so he gives Kafka a "catch you later" gesture and turns onto his own usual stool at the bar. Kafka stares at his friends over there.  They're taking off their coats and  greeting other people.  The girl, Anna, is the first to start walking to join him. He starts to write, a first line that has occurred to him, the pen moving as if he can't help himself ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna's approaching.  Kafka just watches her coming.  He knows he'll end up going out with her, sleeping with her, getting engaged to her ... We see the future on Kafka's face
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dearest Father ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You asked me recently why I maintain that I am afraid of you ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Alone again in his little room, Kafka writes on into the night.  The famous "Letter To His Father" is pages and pages long.  We notice too that his chest has been bandaged.  He
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a little as he forces himself to keep writing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Naturally things cannot in reality fit together the way the evidence does in my letter
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: life is more than a Chinese puzzle.  But in my opinion something has been achieved which so closely approximates the truth that it might reassure us both a little and make our living and our dying easier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: FADE OUT FADE IN WATERFRONT WHARVES
